author: Jonathan Walker
title: Is saving North East jobs more important than cutting immigration rates?
text:
Is saving North East jobs more important than cutting immigration rates? 18:00, 12 Oct 2016 By Jonathan Walker Sedgefield's Labour MP Phil Wilson says tens of thousands of jobs depend on the UK's access to the EU markets   Views inside Hitachi train factory at Newton Aycliffe where new East Coast trains will be built 
Putting a crackdown on EU migration ahead of the economy could threaten thousands of jobs in the North East, an MP has warned. 
Sedgefield MP Phil Wilson said ensuring British-made products can be sold across Europe was more important than cutting immigration. 
The MP also said the Government and other politicians must listen to the concerns of voters and find ways to get immigration numbers down. 
But he said: “At the end of the day, what actually trumps immigration is economic wellbeing and jobs.” 
He joined other MPs in the North East who are concerned about the impact Brexit could have on investment in the region, where major employers include Japanese firms Hitachi and Nissan . 
As long as the UK remains in the EU, goods made in the UK can be sold across the EU. However, if the UK leaves the single market then it’s possible tariffs could be imposed, making British goods more expensive overseas. 
The Government appears to be heading for what has become known as “hard Brexit”, which probably involves leaving the EU single market and also taking back full control over the UK’s borders, allowing the UK to control immigration from EU countries. The new Nissan Qashqai is produced on the assembly line at the Nissan Sunderland plant 
By contrast, the option known as “soft Brexit” would involve continuing as full or partial members of the EU single market, but would probably also mean continuing to accept the principle of freedom of movement so that EU citizens have a right to live and work in the UK. 
Mr Wilson said: “You’ve got implications for foreign domestic investment, particularly in the North East. The Japanese have pointed that out. 
“I know immigration is a big issue but I don’t think people voted to make themselves poorer. 
“I think we have got to look at the impact on immigration and also on the economy if we leave the single market.” 
He added: “There are tens of thousands of jobs in the North East which are reliable on future trade existing and future trade with the single market.” 
Mr Wilson pointed out that official figures show more than half of migrants to the UK actually come from countries outside the EU. This shows that leaving the EU will not put an end to immigration in any case, he said. Read More Theresa May's cynical mockery of the decent liberal values I treasure is outrageous 
He criticised senior Conservative politicians who backed the ‘Leave’ campaign, saying: “The Government obviously didn’t have a contingency plan for a leave vote. 
“And secondly, those people that have been promoting us leaving the EU for decades now, and I mean the likes of Liam Fox and David Davis, don’t seem to have a plan.” Video loading Click to play Tap to play The Live Event you are trying to watch is either unavailable or has not started Please refresh this page in your browser to reload this live event video 
In September, the Japanese Government issued a stark warning that businesses in Japan may reduce investment in the UK if trade restrictions are put in place. 
It said in a letter: “Japanese businesses with their European headquarters in the UK may decide to transfer their head office function to Continental Europe if EU laws cease to be applicable in the UK after its withdrawal.” 
And it warned that manufacturers, “especially of automobiles”, have raised concerns that they will be hit by trade tariffs. 
Speaking in the House of Commons on Wednesday, David Davis, the Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union, insisted the Government would not share its plans for leaving the EU in any detail at this point. 
Tory heavyweights Ken Clarke and former attorney general Dominic Grieve suggested MPs should get a vote on the Brexit blueprint. 
Prime Minister Theresa May has announced the UK will trigger article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, the official mechanism for leaving the EU, by the end of March 2017. 
It means the UK could be out of the EU by the summer of 2019.
